title: Editorial : Hikurangi scenario shows 22 , 000 Kiwis could die in a quake - are we doing enough to prepare ?

During a session on catastrophic risk, the National Emergency Management Agency (Nema) detailed its work over the past 18 months, using a 9.1 Hikurangi earthquake and tsunami as its “planning scenario” for the “worst of the worst”.

On a nationwide, governmental level, we must ensure our systems are ready to cope with a disaster.

title: Why holdover , or  zombie , wildfires are a bigger problem for B . C . this year
message:
But crews are also watching one of the largest wildfires burning in Western Canada — the Patry Creek fire, 25 kilometres north of Fort Nelson, B.C.
Wildfire Service put out an early warning that with dry conditions, these holdover fires could pose a bigger threat than in years past.

These are the regions, he said, where large fires burned last year, putting them at greatest risk of having holdover fires return.

title: Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes lost in B . C . wildfire
message:
Rob Fraser says three of the four homes were occupied and one was vacant, but he’s been able to speak with most of the owners whose properties have been damaged.
Fraser says the affected properties were on the outskirts of Fort Nelson, and the six others saw damage to sheds, shops and vehicles.
I mean, this is the start of a potentially really long season,” Fraser said Sunday.
Fire crews have also placed “structural protection measures” on 200 homes in Fort Nelson, and crews are being aided by both helicopters and heavy equipment, the update said.
The Patry Creek wildfire to the north of the town doesn’t pose an immediate threat, but the municipality warned the situation could change rapidly in the event of strong northerly winds.
event_breakdown:
List Report :
1. Six homes were damaged by the Patry Creek wildfire in the north of Fort Nelson.
2. The Patry Creek wildfire does not pose an immediate threat to Fort Nelson.
3. Fire crews have placed "structural protection measures" on 200 homes in Fort Nelson.

title: Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes lost in B . C . wildfire
message:
FORT NELSON, B.C.
— The Mayor of British Columbia's Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes have been lost and six other properties have been damaged by a wildfire that forced the evacuation of Fort Nelson more than a week ago.
FORT NELSON, B.C.
— The Mayor of British Columbia's Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes have been lost and six other properties have been damaged by a wildfire that forced the evacuation of Fort Nelson more than a week ago.
Fire crews have also placed "structural protection measures" on 200 homes in Fort Nelson, and crews are being aided by both helicopters and heavy equipment, the update said.

message:

title: Hot Weather Poses New Risk as Thousands Remain Without Power After Deadly Houston Storm
message:
“Don’t overdo yourself during the cleanup process,” the weather service’s Houston office said in a post on the social platform X.
In addition to the heat, the Houston area could face poor air quality during the weekend.
HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS REMAIN WITHOUT POWERThe widespread destruction of Thursday’s storms brought much of Houston to a standstill.
School districts in the Houston area canceled classes Friday for more than 400,000 students and government offices were closed.
“It felt terrifying.”STATE AND FEDERAL RECOVERY ASSISTANCE ON THE WAYIn light of the storm damage, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo and Whitmire both signed disaster declarations, paving the way for state and federal storm recovery assistance.
event_breakdown:
* Strong storm on Thursday in the Houston area

February 14th, 2021: Over 4 million people lose power in Texas. This was caused by a combination of extreme cold, ice, and snow, and too much of the electric grid in Texas was poorly prepared for the weather.
February 18th, 2021: Several other cities in the state also faced power outages, including Abilene (Austin), Austin (Houston), Houston (Killeen), Killeen (San Antonio), San Angelo (Eagle Pass - Laredo) due to ice.

title: Deadly storms leave Houston area reeling with power outages and health risks
message:
Thunderstorms and hurricane-force winds tore through the city - decimating the facade of one brick building and leaving trees, debris and shattered glass on the streets.

Another 21,000 customers were also without power in Louisiana, where strong winds and a suspected tornado hit.
"You know we don't have any power.
"I could definitely tell that this storm was a little different," she said.

title: BMKG prepares joint expedition to explore earthquake zones
message:
BMKG prepares joint expedition to explore earthquake zonesJakarta (ANTARA) - The Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) has begun preparing expeditions to investigate seismic phenomena in the megathrust zones in Indonesia, the agency's head, Dwikorita Karnawati, said on Sunday.The expeditions will be conducted by the BMKG and the National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN) for research and data collection.Karnawati said the expeditions will explore all megathrust zones in Indonesia: Sunda Subduction, Banda Subduction, Sulawesi Subduction, Philippine Sea Plate Subduction, Maluku Sea Plate Subduction, and North Papua Subduction.
"We've begun preparing everything, including research, training, and development centers, to create earthquake and tsunami models," she said.BMKG Head of Public Meteorology, Andri Ramdhani, said that the expeditions will begin in Batam, Riau Islands, and travel through several cities before reaching Bitung, North Sulawesi, on August 25.The research will involve a series of long voyages using OceanX's OceanXplorer ship.OceanX is a global non-profit organization in the field of marine exploration that collaborates with the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment to research Indonesian seas.The expeditions will not only investigate earthquake phenomena but also observe the interaction of air and sea in Indonesian waters.The target is areas that are identified as locations for phenomena influenced by Indonesia's weather and climate variability, such as the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO), and the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD).BMKG considers this research exploration crucial because natural and sometimes periodic changes in air and ocean circulation, volcanic eruptions, and other factors influence climate variability.Furthermore, only 19 percent of Indonesia's vast seas (over 70 percent of the country's area) have been mapped, highlighting the need for exploration, as Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan stated in a recent coordination meeting.
"Preparations with OceanX are complete.
The BMKG is also bringing equipment to measure relevant parameters and continues coordination, especially with the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment as the leading sector," said Ramdhani.
Translator: M. Riezko Bima Elko Prasetyo, KatrianaEditor: Anton SantosoCopyright © ANTARA 2024

title: Hot weather poses new risk as thousands remain without power after deadly Houston storm
message:
Hot weather poses new risk as thousands remain without power after deadly Houston stormKaren Warren / Houston Chronicle via Associated PressHOUSTON — As the Houston area works to clean up and restore power to hundreds of thousands after deadly storms left at least seven people dead, it will do so amid a smog warning and scorching temperatures that could pose health risks.
“Don’t overdo yourself during the cleanup process,” the weather service’s Houston office said in a post on the social platform X.
In addition to the heat, the Houston area could face poor air quality during the weekend.
HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS REMAIN WITHOUT POWERThe widespread destruction of Thursday's storms brought much of Houston to a standstill.
School districts in the Houston area canceled classes Friday for more than 400,000 students and government offices were closed.

What are natural-disasters text Events?
The events that can be placed on a map and described as significant geological or meteorological phenomena are considered naturalistic disasters in the text. These events include earthquakes, tsunamis, floods, and storms. These events can be recorded as having taken place at specific times and locations, and impacts can extend over wide areas. The geographical extent of the event can be the radius of the event impact on the multitude.

When several natural-disaster events are related to each other, they are often grouped into a single event, with a location. This can help people to understand the impact of a series of events on an area. For example, an earthquake followed by a tsunami would be recorded as if it occurred in the same location, but time would if the list of events were on the same day as the one preceding event.

title: At least 66 dead as new floods hit Afghanistan Faryab province | Floods News
message:
Fresh floods have killed at least 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, says a provincial official, in the latest deadly string of disasters to hit the country in recent days.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night “resulted in human and financial losses”, Asmatullah Moradi, spokesman for the Faryab governor, said in a statement on Sunday.
“Due to the floods 66 people were killed,” he said, adding that at least five people were injured and several others missing.
Another 18 people had also died in floods in the same province on Friday, Moradi added.
The latest disaster in Faryab came just a day after provincial authorities said 50 people were killed in flash flooding just south of the province in Ghor.

title: Thousands march in Cork town to demand flood protection measures
message:
Thousands have marched through a Cork town devastated by flooding last October to "scream out" for interim flood protection measures before the next storm season.
Organisers of the rally through Midleton in East Cork, the Midleton and East Cork Flood Protection Group, said they hope the event sends a clear message to government that they want and need urgent action over the coming months to protect homes, businesses and lives pending the delivery of the €50m Midleton flood relief scheme.
They need to start doing some of these interim works this summer.
In addition, Individual Property Protection (IPP) “is being considered” as part of the overall suite of measures for Midleton, the OPW said.
“A decision on this is expected shortly, so IPP can be rolled out by Cork County Council on a phased and targeted basis,” a spokesperson said.

title: Power expected to be restored to most affected by deadly Houston storm
message:
Power restored to most affected by deadly Houston storm, with the rest by WednesdayHOUSTON (AP) — Houston area residents affected by deadly storms last week received some good news as officials said power had been restored Sunday to a majority of the hundreds of thousands who had been left in the dark and without air conditioning amid hot and humid weather.
By Sunday evening, 88% of customers in the Houston area had their power restored, said Paul Lock, a spokesperson for CenterPoint Energy.
More than 289,000 homes and businesses in Texas remained without electricity Sunday evening, mostly in the Houston area.
CenterPoint Energy said 2,000 employees and more than 5,000 contractors were working in the Houston area to restore power.
Two other large school districts in the the Houston area — Cypress-Fairbanks and Spring Branch — planned to be closed.

title: Texas Will Feel The Wrath of La Niña , Starting This Summer
message:
The eastward winds of El Niño are fading, but a terrible little girl we know as La Niña is brewing on the horizon.
With El Niño, the temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean drop by half a degree Celsius; with El Niña, the inverse holds true.
The key difference between El Niño and La Niña in how it impacts Texas is that the former brings about a wet winter, the latter brings warmer, drier weather.
There may be a period of neutral weather, but we can expect a rapid cycle over to La Niña by June or August at the latest.

Artificial land is generally lower in elevation, and it cannot always hold as much weight as natural land without subsiding, Kunkel said.
That means the artificial land is both more vulnerable to sea level rise and more difficult to protect from flooding with heavy sea walls.
(Humanity still has time to reach net zero global emissions by 2050; if we do, sea level rise would likely be less.)

title: How  kitty cat are wrecking the home insurance industry
message:
The rising cost of homeowner’s insurance is now one of the most prominent symptoms of climate change in the United States.
Losses from severe convective storms increased by about 9 percent every year between 1989 and 2022, according to the insurance firm Aon.
But climate change may also be playing a role: Convective storms tend to form in hot, moist, and unstable weather conditions.
Even large “reinsurers,” which sell insurance to insurance companies around the world, are feeling the sting from these storms.
But the increasing trend of “attritional” losses from repeated convective storms does threaten to cut into their profit margins.

2. Severe convective storms have certain weather conditions that prompt their formation.

4. Severe convective wind events led to attritional losses for insurers constantly.

title: Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan : provincial official
message:
Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan: provincial officialKabul, May 19 (AFP) May 19, 2024Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in the latest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night "resulted in human and financial losses," Asmatullah Muradi, spokesman for the Faryab governor, said in a statement.
"Due to the floods 66 people were killed," he said, adding that at least five people were injured and others were still missing.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Just over a week ago, more than 300 people were killed in flash flooding in northern Baghlan province, according to the UN World Food Programme and Taliban officials.

Hundreds of people have died in separate flash floods this month that have also swamped farmland in a country where 80 percent of the population depends on agriculture to survive.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Residents in Baghlan, Ghor, Faryab and other affected regions found themselves without shelter, stripped of their homes and livelihoods.
Spring floods are not uncommon in Afghanistan, a country of more than 40 million people, but above-average rainfall this year has sparked devastating flash flooding.

title: Power expected to be restored to most affected by deadly Houston storm
message:
Power expected to be restored to most affected by deadly Houston stormPower expected to be restored to most affected by deadly Houston storm View PhotoHOUSTON (AP) — Houston area residents affected by deadly storms last week that left at least seven dead were finally getting some good news as officials said they expected power to be restored by Sunday evening to a majority of the hundreds of thousands still in the dark and without air conditioning amid hot and humid weather.
More than 352,000 homes and businesses in Texas remained without electricity Sunday morning, with most of those in the Houston area.
CenterPoint Energy said it anticipated that about 80% of affected customers in the Houston area would have service restored by Sunday evening.
CenterPoint Energy said 2,000 employees and more than 5,000 contractors were working in the Houston area to restore power.
The Houston Independent School District, the state’s largest, said power had been restored to nearly 200 campuses and those schools would be open Monday.

title: Flash floods kill 50 in western Afghanistan
message:
— X@WFP_Afghanistan/FileKABUL: Flash flooding has killed at least 50 people in western Afghanistan, provincial police said Saturday, with some residents reaching safety on higher ground mere minutes before the water hit.
The fresh flooding in the country -- which has experienced above-average rainfall this spring -- comes after flash floods on May 10 in northern Baghlan province washed away hundreds.
“Fifty residents of Ghor province were killed by the floods on Friday and a number of others are missing,” Badri said.
“These terrible floods have also killed thousands of cattle...
“Within five minutes of our escape, a huge and horrible flash flood came and washed away everything.

title: Danger behind the beauty : more solar storms could be heading our way
message:
‘Danger behind the beauty’: more solar storms could be heading our wayAirlines sometimes change routes during extreme solar storms.
“We need to understand that behind this beauty, there is danger,” Quentin Verspieren, the European Space Agency’s space safety programme coordinator, told AFP.
– What threat do solar storms pose?
The most famous example came in 1859 during the worst solar storm in recorded history, called the Carrington Event.
Airlines sometimes change routes during extreme solar storms to avoid this happening, he added.

title: A  drifting  postbox for letters to people who died in the 2011 Japan Earthquake kept running
message:
May 20, 2024MORIOKA – A unique postbox that receives letters with messages for people who died in the 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake stands on the Hirota Peninsula in Rikuzen-Takata, Iwate Prefecture.
However, when he saw people who had lost their family members due to the Noto Peninsula Earthquake, he changed his mind.
Akagawa named the postbox “Drifting 3.11 Postbox” as it is the place where letters with nowhere to go would end up drifting.
Amid such circumstances, the situation in the areas hit by the Jan. 1 Noto Peninsula Earthquake reminded Akagawa of the situation immediately after the 2011 disaster.
“I am relieved that I could find a new custodian of the postbox,” Akagawa said.

title: Power expected to be restored to most affected by deadly Houston storm
message:
HOUSTON — Houston area residents affected by deadly storms last week that left at least seven dead were finally getting some good news as officials said they expected power to be restored by Sunday evening to a majority of the hundreds of thousands still in the dark and without air conditioning amid hot and humid weather.
The widespread destruction of Thursday’s storms brought much of Houston to a standstill.
A tornado also touched down near the northwest Houston suburb of Cypress.
More than 352,000 homes and businesses in Texas remained without electricity Sunday morning, with most of those in the Houston area.
No hot water.

Large electricity towers have been destroyed and schools have been canceled for Friday throughout Houston.

title: Flood Damage A Growing Risk For NZ Kelp Forests
message:
Flood Damage A Growing Risk For NZ’s Kelp ForestsTimber slash and debris from flooding events is decimating Aotearoa New Zealand’s vital underwater kelp forests, a nationwide study shows.
“Sunlight, on which thriving kelp forests depend, is obstructed by this run-off in shallow coastal water.
Our research shows there’s a rapidly accelerating degradation of our iconic kelp forests and this is a major concern for marine biodiversity,” Professor Schiel says.
Kelp forests support many species of invertebrates, sponges and other plants that coastal fish species feed on.
We now need to find ways to improve coastal management and prevent run-off from land damaging kelp forests.
event_breakdown: Floods

title: City of Mission prepares for hurricane season with cleanup project
message:
City of Mission prepares for hurricane season with cleanup projectLoads of tires, old mattresses and other unwanted items were dropped off in Mission on Saturday as the city prepared residents ahead of hurricane season.
The city held a community roundup event at 1400 S. Conway Ave. where residents were allowed to drop off bulky items and tires.
The city says preventing illegal dumping is important, especially in flood-prone areas.
A total of 500 tires were collected, and the city says they plan to hold more of these events in the coming months.

title: Flooding places bridges at risk
message:
THREE bridges connecting Wau-Waria and Bulolo are under threat of being washed away by heavy flooding in Wau, Morobe.
The abutments on the opposite ends of two of the bridges have been washed away by the floods and are standing in the middle of the river.
Pinetop Bridge connecting the two districts is under threat of being swept away by the flooding waters if the rain continues.
Part of the road between Four Road and Koranga Bridge was washed away and is also under threat of being washed away.
Bulolo DDA youth representative Yemon Bisa said hundreds of families have been displaced by the flooding and the DDA had supplied food, cooking utensils and shelter for the displaced families living near Bulolo river.

title: At least 66 people killed in flooding in northern Afghanistan
message:
Local authorities in Afghanistan say floods in the northern province of Faryab have killed at least 66 people.
The provincial authorities said the flooding on Saturday also washed away or damaged around 1,500 houses and left eight people missing.
Afghanistan has been hit by a series of flash floods due to heavy rains this month.
Providing assistance to those affected by the flooding, and restoring their livelihoods, are major challenges for Afghanistan.
The country is facing economic difficulties, as well as food shortages, under the rule of the Taliban which retook power three years ago.
event_breakdown:
- Flooding in the northern Afghan province of Faryab killed 66 people
- The flooding also destroyed or damaged around 1,500 houses

title: Q1 Global Insured Natural Disaster Losses Driven by Severe Convective Storms : Aon
message:
Global natural catastrophes cost insurers $17 billion during the first quarter of 2024 with economic losses rising above $45 billion, according to Aon’s Q1 Global Catastrophe Recap – April 2024.
Q1 natural disaster losses were driven by severe convective and winter storms in the United States, as well as windstorms and flooding in Europe, and the earthquake in Japan, the Aon report said.
The global Q1 insured losses of $17 billion were close to the average since 2000 ($16 billion) and higher than the median of $12 billion for that period.
Economic losses of $45 billion, were lower than the 21st century Q1 average of $59 billion and significantly lower than losses of $149 billion reported during Q1 2023.
The insurance protection gap (or the difference between total economic losses and the amount covered by insurers) was estimated at 64%; only 36% of global economic losses were insured.
event_breakdown:
- Severe convective and winter storms in the US caused $17 billion in Q1 2024 insured losses.
- Windstorms and flooding in Europe caused $20 billion in Q1 2024 insured losses.
- Earthquake in Japan caused $9 billion in Q1 2024 insured losses.

title: Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes lost in B . C . wildfire | iNFOnews

title: Governor Abbott requests disaster assistance for additional counties impacted by weather
message:
AUSTIN, Texas (KBTX) - KBTX spoke with Walker County Emergency Management Sunday afternoon who told us FEMA is on the ground accessing flooding and storm damage.
On Friday, Walker County was among the Texas counties approved by President Biden in the state’s request for a Major Disaster Declaration.
It was a partial approval, and on Sunday, Governor Abbott announced he was requesting FEMA disaster assistance for additional counties.
Governor Abbott’s request for FEMA’s Public Assistance program, which would ensure eligibility for 26 designated counties to utilize grant funding, remains under review.
In our area that includes Grimes, Leon, Madison, Milam, Montgomery and Walker counties.

title: Power restored to most hit by deadly Houston storm with full service expected by Wednesday
message:
Power restored to most hit by deadly Houston storm with full service expected by WednesdayHOUSTON (AP) — Houston area residents affected by deadly storms last week received some good news as officials said power was restored Sunday to a majority of the hundreds of thousands who had been left in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather.
By Sunday evening, 88% of customers in the Houston area had their power restored, said Paul Lock, a spokesperson for CenterPoint Energy.
CenterPoint Energy said 2,000 employees and more than 5,000 contractors were working in the Houston area to restore power.
At least 15 community centers were set to serve as cooling centers in the Houston area on Monday.
Two other large school districts in the the Houston area, Cypress-Fairbanks and Spring Branch, planned to be closed.

title: SunLive - Flood damage : Growing risk for NZ kelp forests
message:
Timber slash and debris from flooding events is decimating Aotearoa New Zealand’s vital underwater kelp forests, a nationwide study shows.
“Sunlight, on which thriving kelp forests depend, is obstructed by this run-off in shallow coastal water.
“Our research shows there’s a rapidly accelerating degradation of our iconic kelp forests and this is a major concern for marine biodiversity,.” .
Kelp forests support many species of invertebrates, sponges and other plants that coastal fish species feed on.
We now need to find ways to improve coastal management and prevent run-off from land damaging kelp forests.

title: Maine to Spend $25 Million to Rebuild Waterfront Damaged by Winter Storms
message:
Maine waterfrontMaine’s government will spend tens of millions of dollars to rebuild the state’s working waterfront communities after a series of devastating winter storms pummeled the state’s docks, wharves and coastal businesses.
State officials in Maine said the storms, which were later declared a “major disaster” by President Joe Biden, caused about $70 million in damage in the state.
Applications for funding are now available to repair and rebuild working waterfront areas damaged by the storms, Democratic Gov.
The $25 million being made available is part of a $60 million rebuilding package approved by the Maine Legislature for storm rebuilding, Mills said.
Our working waterfront must be preserved for future generations by ensuring it is resilient to a changing climate,” Keliher said.

title: 3 . 4 magnitude tremor hits Kutch in Gujarat ; no casualty
message:
Ahmedabad: A tremor of 3.4 magnitude hit Gujarat’s Kutch district on Monday, the Institute of Seismological Research (ISR) said.
It has suffered nine major earthquakes in the past 200 years, as per the information provided by the Gujarat State Disaster Management Authority (GSDMA).
The 2001 Kutch earthquake was the third largest and second most destructive in India over the last two centuries, it said.
On January 26, 2001, Gujarat was struck by a 6.9 magnitude earthquake with its epicentre located near Bhachau in Kutch which affected the entire state.
The quake had claimed nearly 13,800 lives and left 1.67 lakh others injured, as per the information provided by the GSDMA.

title: Afghanistan floods highlight risks of extreme weather events to children - Afghanistan
message:
KABUL, 20 May 2024 – Afghanistan has been hit by flash floods twice in the span of one week, highlighting the country’s susceptibility to extreme weather events and the impact on children.
Floods at the weekend in the western province of Ghor and Faryab province in the north brought further devastation and killed at least 110* people, including children.
Arshad Malik, Country Director of Save the Children Afghanistan, said:“Extreme weather events pose a serious risk to all children in Afghanistan whose families or communities rely on farming to survive.
This equates to nearly 13.2 million children or 70% of children in Afghanistan.
Notes*At least 50 people were killed as of Saturday 18 May in Ghor province, according to figures given by the de facto authorities.
event_breakdown: Natural disasters events include flash floods in the western province of Ghor and Faryab province in the North of Afghanistan, devastating and killing at least 110 people, including children.

title: Heaviest Pa . storms drop 60 % more rain than they used to , report says
message:
A report from the nonprofit science communication group Climate Central says climate change is causing the heaviest storms in Pennsylvania and other northeastern states to drop 60% more rain than they did six decades ago.
That’s because a warmer atmosphere can hold more moisture, which can fuel heavy rain events and flash floods.
Climate CentralGreg Carbin, chief of forecast operations at the National Weather Service Weather Prediction Center, was not involved in the report.
Carbin said it can be difficult to get people to recognize how dangerous a rain event is, but flooding can destroy homes, sweep away cars, and claim lives.
One solution, she said, could be infrastructure that can absorb and hold water during storms, rather than transporting all of it somewhere else.
event_breakdown: Rain events

title: Hillsborough County pushes landscaping prep for hurricane season
message:
With hurricane season just days away, now is the time to start working on your plan for preparation.
Hillsborough County continued their "Make a Plan Monday" series this week by focusing on something many Floridians may overlook : landscaping.
"Start with the biggest things that you have in your landscaping that you know you need to move," advises Lynn Barber, extension agent with Hillsborough County.
Large debris also has the chance to block streets and clog storm drains, creating more work for storm relief crews.
For more information on Hurricane Preparedness in Hillsborough County, click here.
event_breakdown:
- Hurricane season
- Storm relief crews

title: U . S . hasnt seen an EF5 tornado in 11 years , longest gap in history
message:
File Photo by J.P. Wilson/UPI | License PhotoAn EF5 tornado is one of the most catastrophic weather events on Earth.
AdvertisementBefore the Moore tornado, the blockbuster tornado season in 2011 led to the confirmation of five EF5 twisters, including the Joplin, Missouri, EF5 that killed 161 people.
Because most weather instruments can't survive tornadoes, the EF scale estimates tornado strength based on NWS staff investigating damage indicators.
This precedent was reaffirmed by the El Reno tornado on May 31, 2013, which tracked just south of El Reno, Oklahoma.
Because of the damage found, the El Reno tornado, despite being the largest twister ever recorded at 2.6 miles wide, was confirmed as an EF3.
event_breakdown: Tornadoes, EF5 tornados, El Reno tornado, EF3 tornado

title: Fort McMurray wildfire classified as  being held
message:
Send this page to someone via emailA wildfire burning near Fort McMurray in northeastern Alberta is now classified as “being held.”In an update at 7 p.m. Sunday, Alberta Wildfire downgraded the status of the wildfire, which was previously classified as out of control.
“Given current weather conditions and resources, the wildfire is not anticipated to grow past expected boundaries,” Alberta Wildfire said in its Sunday evening update.
Story continues below advertisementThe wildfire danger is low in the Fort McMurray Forest Area.
“Firefighters and heavy equipment operators have been able to take advantage of the recent rain to make excellent progress on containing the wildfire,” Alberta Wildfire said.
For the latest information on the wildfire status and danger across the province, visit the Alberta Wildfire website.
event_breakdown:
Based on the text you provided, here are the natural-disasters events listed in chronological order:

1. A wildfire is burning near Fort McMurray in northeastern Alberta.
2. The wildfire is now classified as “being held.”
3. The wildfire danger is low in the Fort McMurray Forest Area.

It's worth noting that these events are not independent and are all part of the same wildfire near Fort McMurray.

title: Status of wildfire that threatened Fort McMurray changed to  being held  – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
FORT MCMURRAY, Alta.
– A wildfire that forced thousands of people to evacuate several Fort McMurray neighbourhoods last week is no longer classified as out-of-control.
A wildfire that forced thousands of people to evacuate several Fort McMurray neighbourhoods last week is no longer classified as out-of-control.
An evacuation alert for the entire city of Fort McMurray, which told residents they should be ready to leave at short notice, was lifted at the same time.
Alberta Wildfire says over 40 millimetres of rain has fallen on the fire since May 16.
event_breakdown: The wildfire in Fort McMurray, Alberta, is no longer classified as out-of-control.

title: Forecast First Alert : Strong storms possible Tuesday afternoon for Minnesota , Wisconsin
message:
Thunderstorms rumbled through the Twin Cities early Monday morning, with a 5 EYEWITNESS NEWS photographer capturing video of distant lightning.
Although rain and storms are possible during the early morning hours, another round of stronger storms is possible later in the day, just in time for the drive home from work.
Severe and strong storms are most likely to hit southeastern Minnesota and southern Wisconsin on Tuesday, as well as a large part of Iowa – however, the storm system is still forming, and the exact target area has yet to be determined.
Expect heavy rain, potentially enough for flash flooding and lingering river flooding.
Currently, rain totals from Sunday night through Tuesday night may total 1-2″, but areas with stronger storms could push some totals as high as 4″.
location: The most specific location mentioned in the text is the Twin Cities in Minnesota, United States.
event_breakdown:
.
- 2022 Minneapolis–Saint Paul storms
- Storm system causing heavy rainfall in Southeastern Minnesota and Southern Wisconsin
- Potential for flash flooding in southeastern Minnesota and southern Wisconsin
- Storm system forming in Iowa
- Potential for heavy rain and flash flooding in Iowa

title: South Florida leaders hold roundtable to discuss upcoming hurricane season
message:
MIAMI-DADE COUNTY, Fla. – As hurricane season quickly approaches, emergency officials are working to get South Florida residents and visitors prepared.
Kevin Guthrie, the Executive Director of the Florida Division of Emergency Management, held a roundtable discussion with local emergency management officials at the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Training Facility on Monday to address the upcoming hurricane season.
Emergency management leaders from Miami-Dade and Broward counties attended the meeting to discuss the importance of organized evacuations, fuel shelters and resident preparation in what officials describe as a “supercharged season.”“It’s supposed to be a supercharged season, maybe the highest on record that we’ve ever had,” said Guthrie.
Click here to view Local 10′s Hurricane Survival Guide.
To receive updated hurricane news and analysis from Local 10′s weather team, click here.

title: This wildfire season , changes are coming to better inform people about smoke hazards | iNFOnews
message:
Vernon News This wildfire season, changes are coming to better inform people about smoke hazardsLast year’s record-breaking wildfire season forced Canadians to become familiar with the scale of air pollution as hazardous smoke drifted across the country.
Image Credit: THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jason FransonLast year’s record-breaking wildfire season forced Canadians to become familiar with the scale of air pollution as hazardous smoke drifted across the country.
Users can now toggle between different layers of active alerts and display only those related to air quality if that’s their main concern.
When the AQHI exceeds 10 due to wildfire smoke — indicating a “very high” health risk — affected areas appear red on the map.
This change was prompted by a “record number” of AQHI 10+ scores during last year’s wildfire season, she said in a phone interview.
event_breakdown:
.
- Last year's record-breaking wildfire season
- Active alerts related to air quality
- Different layers of active alerts
- 10+ scores during the wildfire season

title: 4 . 1 Magnitude Earthquake Reported In US
message:
A 4.1-magnitude earthquake struck California on Monday (May 20), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Ocotillo Wells with a 11.2 kilometer (about 7.0 miles) depth.
The California earthquake struck hours after a 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck China on Monday, according to the United States Geological Survey.
The China earthquake struck two days after a 4.7-magnitude earthquake was reported in Japan on Saturday (May 18), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Tomioka with a 35.4 kilometer (about 30 miles) depth.

A 4.1-magnitude earthquake struck California on Monday (May 20), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Ocotillo Wells with a 11.2 kilometer (about 7.0 miles) depth.
The California earthquake struck hours after a 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck China on Monday, according to the United States Geological Survey.
The China earthquake struck two days after a 4.7-magnitude earthquake was reported in Japan on Saturday (May 18), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Tomioka with a 35.4 kilometer (about 30 miles) depth.
event_breakdown:
Natural disasters:
1. California earthquake - 4.1 magnitude - centered in Ocotillo Wells
2. China earthquake - 5.1 magnitude - centered in Tomioka
3. Japan earthquake - 4.7 magnitude - centered in Tomioka

title: U . S . wildfire season is now everywhere , all at once
message:
Mark Gongloff is a Bloomberg Opinion editor and columnist covering climate change.
The toxic smoke choking swathes of the Midwestern U.S. this week is a helpful reminder to Americans that Canada exists, and its wildfire season has come early.
But Americans shouldn’t forget their own season starts much earlier these days, too.
In fact, it’s getting to the point that wildfire season is all year long.
In some parts of the Southwestern U.S., wildfire season is now two months longer than in 1973, with about half of that increase coming in the spring.
event_breakdown:
So there are three types of events:
- The wildfires in Canada,
- The wildfires in the American South-West and
- The toxic smoke in America.

title: Active hurricane season could have  detrimental impact  on home insurance
message:
The predictions for Florida's upcoming hurricane season are serious, with numerous storms predicted.
"Large losses would have a detrimental impact on Florida's recovering market," said Mark Friedlander of the Insurance Information Institute.
Weather Forecasters predict a well-above-average Atlantic hurricane season Evan ThomasColorado State University's predictions, which are typically factored into insurance modeling, show Florida with a 75% chance of being impacted by a hurricane.
"Large loss events always impact insurance markets, no matter how strong those insurance markets are," Friedlander said.
"If you have a heavy volume of loss activity during hurricane season, it's going to change the dynamics."
event_breakdown: Hurricane season

title: An off - the - grid island beach cottage is now for sale in the Florida Keys
message:
There are only about a dozen homes on Florida's isolated Cook Island, and now one of them is for sale.Located at 3 W. Cook Burg Pne., the beach cottage was built in 1985 and is truly "off-the-grid" in just about every way.There are no utilities on Cook Island, so the home uses solar power and gets its water from a rain cistern.Accessible only by boat or seaplane, Cook Island sits near Big Pine Island in the Florida Keys, and was first settled by Captain Percy Cook in the 1920s.
For years was it used as a fish camp for wintering vacationers from the north.Though sparsely populated, Cook Island bore the brunt of Hurricane Irma, which damaged many of the homes, including this one, when the storm made landfall as a Category 4 hurricane in 2017.Today, the cottage has been raised from the sand.
Its 704 square feet of living space include three bedrooms and two bathrooms.
It also comes with a dock permit, since the old one appears to have been blown away.Asking price for the beach cottage is currently $799,000 and the listing agents are Dave Wiley and Banks G. Prevatt of Coldwell Banker Schmitt RE Co. Lower Keys Office.
event_breakdown:
The natural-disaster events mentioned are:
- Hurricane Irma (landfall on Florida's Cook Island, Category 4 hurricane with winds 130 mph and storm surges)
- Hurricane Irma caused damage to many homes on Fla.'s isolated Cook Island

title: Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes lost in wildfire
message:
The Mayor of British Columbia’s Northern Rockies Regional Municipality says four homes have been lost and six other properties have been damaged by a wildfire that forced the evacuation of Fort Nelson more than a week ago.
Rob Fraser says three of the four homes were occupied and one was vacant, but he’s been able to speak with most of the owners whose properties have been damaged.
Fraser says the affected properties were on the outskirts of Fort Nelson, and the six others saw damage to sheds, shops and vehicles.
In an update posted late Saturday, the municipality said forecasted rain has provided "a window for progress," but problematic drought conditions remain.
Fire crews have also placed "structural protection measures" on 200 homes in Fort Nelson, and crews are being aided by both helicopters and heavy equipment, the update said.
event_breakdown: Wildfire, drought

title: Essential Items You Need in Your Louisiana Hurricane Kit
message:
The first day of Hurricane Season is two weeks away, so that means t's time to get your hurricane preparedness kit stocked up and ready to be used if you need it.
Hurricane Ida Makes Landfall In Louisiana Leaving Devastation In Its Wake Getty Images loading...
The American Red Cross has published a guide of key items you should have in your hurricane kit.
I recommend getting plastic totes to store the items in so they can be stored easily and moved to a vehicle if you need to evacuate.

title: Waynesville Rural Fire Protection District receives federal funding to improve wildfire defense
message:
(KY3/Editied Release) - The Waynesville Rural Fire Protection District is one of two agencies that received funding from the USDA Forest Service.
According to a news release, the fire department received $250,000 for community wildfire defense.
The grant will help the department develop a community wildfire protection plan (CWPP) for Pulaski County.
“Funding for this CWPP development grant comes from the Community Wildfire Defense Grant Program, which is designed to assist communities (including Tribal communities), nonprofit organizations, and state forestry agencies with planning for and mitigating wildfire risks.
The second agency that received funding was Specialty Lumber Solutions for their Missouri Community Biochar Production Project.
event_breakdown:
1. Wildfires
2. Planned Municipal Wildfire Defence
3. Community Wildfire Protection Plans

title: SD ranks third in U . S . for wildfire risk , repair costs nearly doubled since 2019
message:
SD ranks third in U.S. for wildfire risk, repair costs nearly doubled since 2019SAN DIEGO (FOX 5/KUSI) — Wildfire season in California has just begun and Cal Fire has already reported nearly 800 wildfires since the start of the year.
However, although the rankings have remained the same as 2019, the number of homes at high-extreme wildfire risk and cost value for reconstruction have nearly doubled, according to CoreLogic.
Locally, in the San Diego region, there were over 75,000 homes deemed at high-extreme risk in 2019.
In fact, 10 of the 15 areas with the highest wildfire risk in the country are in the Golden State.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to FOX 5 San Diego & KUSI News.
event_breakdown:
Here are the natural-disasters events mentioned in the text:

- Wildfires in California
- Homes deemed at high-extreme wildfire risk in the San Diego region
- 10 of the 15 areas with the highest wildfire risk in the country are in California

title: Severe weather threat looms over SE Michigan -- Here what to expect
message:
It is hot and humid across Southeast Michigan, and an active weather pattern is giving Metro Detroit back-to-back chances of severe weather.
4Warn Weather – It is hot and humid across Southeast Michigan, and an active weather pattern gives Metro Detroit back-to-back chances of severe weather.
As temperatures rise into the mid-upper 80s, showers and thunderstorms will develop in the afternoon and evening.
A few showers and thunderstorms could once again become strong to severe during the day.

title: Houston power outages persist amid sweltering heat
message:
Houston in Texas is still grappling with the effects of a massive storm that swept through the US south last week, including widespread power outages that have persisted for days in increasingly hotter weather.
The National Weather Service said “heat index values will be approaching/exceeding 100F throughout the week” in south-east Texas.
Students suffered in sweltering heat in classrooms without working air conditioning, sparking outcry from teachers, parents, and lawmakers.
Texas is no stranger to widespread power outages.
The National Weather Service told residents in the city to stay hydrated and to call 911 if experiencing symptoms of heatstroke, which include confusion and dizziness.
event_breakdown:
This events include:
- A storm that swept through the US south last week
- Widespread power outages in south-east Texas
- Increasing heat without air conditioning in classrooms

title: Hot Tuesday with increasing rain and storm chance through midweek
message:
Hot Tuesday with increasing rain and storm chances through midweekINDIANAPOLIS (WISH) — Monday was as hot as advertised with temperatures getting into the mid to upper 80s.
More hot weather is on the way with rain and storm chances increasing over the next couple of days.
There is even a low threat for strong and severe storms in northern Indiana for wind and hail.
Late Tuesday night into early Wednesday may also feature strong to severe storms as there is a low risk along and north of a Sullivan-Indianapolis-Muncie line.
Additional rain and storms will then develop in the latter half of the afternoon hours and into Wednesday night.
event_breakdown:

title: 4 . 1 Magnitude Earthquake Reported In US | NewsRadio 1110 KFAB
message:
A 4.1-magnitude earthquake struck California on Monday (May 20), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Ocotillo Wells with a 11.2 kilometer (about 7.0 miles) depth.
The California earthquake struck hours after a 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck China on Monday, according to the United States Geological Survey.
The China earthquake struck two days after a 4.7-magnitude earthquake was reported in Japan on Saturday (May 18), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The natural disaster was reported to be centered in Tomioka with a 35.4 kilometer (about 30 miles) depth.
event_breakdown:
The natural-disasters events reported in the text are:
- a 4.1-magnitude earthquake in California
- a 5.1-magnitude earthquake in China
- a 4.7-magnitude earthquake in Japan
